foundit66

BYU prof. let go for gay marriage stance
 
 THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
 
 PROVO, Utah -- Brigham Young University has decided not to rehire a part-time instructor because he publicly opposed the Mormon church's stand against marriage for same-sex couples.
 
 Jeffrey Nielsen, a philosophy instructor at the church-owned university, said in an op-ed piece for the June 4 edition of The Salt Lake Tribune, "I believe opposing gay marriage and seeking a constitutional amendment against it is immoral."
 
 Leaders of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints have spent millions of dollars campaigning against gay marriage and on May 28 called on members to support a constitutional amendment banning it.
 
 Nielsen, a Mormon, said he learned of the school's decision regarding his employment in a June 8 letter from Daniel Graham, chairman of the Department of Philosophy.
 
 "Since you have chosen to contradict and oppose the church in an area of great concern to church leaders, and to do so in a public forum, we will not rehire you after the current term is over," the letter said.
 
 BYU spokeswoman Carri Jenkins confirmed that Graham decided not to rehire Nielsen because of the op-ed piece.
 
 Nielsen said he is sticking by his views - and his religion.
 
 "I have no desire to be anything but a member of the church," he said Tuesday.
 
 http://seattlepi.nwsource.com/national/1110AP_Mormons_Gay_Marriage.html

However, lets say the Georgia Tech girl was yelling "no gay rights" in one of the academic buildings. This "speech" is not protected and thus she doesn't have equal protection. I guess you could say that when "equal protection" destroys the very thing you are tring to do, it is generally ok to ignore equal protection.

Would or should a private black university keep or re-hire David Duke?
 Would or should a private gay/lesbian university keep or re-hire Fred Phelps?
 
 If you can honestly answer yes to these, then so be it. 
 
 While I generally support gay/lesbian concerns, I must say this:
 
 BYU is a private university with it's own set of rules, regulations, code, and admission standards which are all clearly spelled out in all of it's literature. They clearly state that they expect the students and staff to conform to a certain set of standards. They also clearly state that if the staff or students do not conform to these standards, that they face sanction up to and including the possibility of expulsion. 
 
 As a private university, they have the right to be as backwards and archaic as they please. If they want to live lives of ignorance and bigotry, so be it. I am willing to bet that over the next 50 years, their enrollment will drop significantly as the public gradually accepts the gay/lesbian lifestyle. 
 
 If you started a private school and stated clearly from the beginning that only gay/lesbian individuals, and those who support the gay/lesbian lifestyle will be admitted, should you be forced to admit members of the Westboro Baptist Church, or keep them if they came out and publically spoke against your policies? Of course not.

I've never understood why any gay man or woman would willingly go to a Christian/religious school or church. You know exactly how they feel about you WAY before you get there. You are never going to change their minds or policies...it's just not happening. In some ways I think it is the need for constant drama in their lives that makes them do it.
 
 I've made it a point that I will no longer set foot in any religious institution for any reason. I will not attend any weddings, funerals, or any other function that is held in a church (of any denomination). I do not go where I am not wanted. I would never think of worshiping god, why bother since he thinks we're abominations while people that murder are simply sinners? God hates us more than people that murder and actually hurt others. It so irrational, that I have no pity on gay people that willingly subject themselves to religious abuse. You went there willingly knowing how they are and think. So stop complaining! Nobody likes a drama queen.
 
 There are plenty of places for us gay people to go that don't hate us and welcome us. Religion is absolutley the last place any gay person should turn to because that is exactly the source of the hate we face every day. If you go there to wallow, then stop complaining when they treat you badly/unfairly. You're pretty dumb if you expected anything else.

post_info.post_title: Why Go To/or Teach At That School?

jyoshu

Why not? The university is church run and by not following the code of the church you are not allowed to work there.

 
 Well for one thing, a university professor should be allowed to have a pretty wide latitude of views to work there--he's a professor. I would just think that, of all jobs, that one should not have a litmus test. 
 
 Another thing is that they are firing him for his views. It would be different if he were being fired for some action taken, but that doesn't seem to be what's happening here. It's easy to jump to action and fire someone we don't agree with, but the world is full of different views. That's the way it is. People who oppose marriage being redefined should be able to disagree and have that dialog without worry of something like this. We don't have to take on the other sides' tendencies; let's leave the tendency toward intolerance and unwillingless to discuss-without-getting-hateful to the gay lobby. 
 
 I realize that this is a private university and as such they are within their rights to get rid of him--I just don't think it's right.
 
 
BYU is a private university with it's own set of rules, regulations, code, and admission standards which are all clearly spelled out in all of it's literature. They clearly state that they expect the students and staff to conform to a certain set of standards. They also clearly state that if the staff or students do not conform to these standards, that they face sanction up to and including the possibility of expulsion.

 
 yes, they do. But that doesn't make it right. This action may have had harmful effect on the professor and his family. I don't think anyone here is questioning the legality of what BYU did.
 
 
I've made it a point that I will no longer set foot in any religious institution for any reason. I will not attend any weddings, funerals, or any other function that is held in a church (of any denomination). 

 
 There are some denominations that are not against gay marriage, and are even in favor of it. Why would you not want to step foot in those buildings?
 
 I would also think that, if you are of the mindset of avoiding and shunning people who don't see things your way, you must live a pretty sheltered life. Over 50% of people in this country do not approve of gay marriage, so if you are consistent at all, you must be trying to avoid a lot more than just religious buildings. Life is full of people who don't agree--that's life. I'd find a tendency to want to dialog and find out what they have to say to be a whole lot more respectable. But with your dogmatic approach, I suspect the churches don't mind too much that you won't step foot inside.

post_info.post_title: The Mormons have their horns in the same place you do.

foundit66

You are well aware of my stance that discrimination against gay people is wrong. I was talking specifically about intolerance in the argumentation itself.

 I can't help but notice a little "missing the big picture" in the specified scope...
 
 Suppose we had a KKK group that was asking that black people should not be able to adopt white babies. And there was a "debate" on the issue.
 The very nature of the debate would be overlooked in your "scope" as you just would focus on whether or not people were "hateful" in their talk on an action item that can be seen as inherently "hateful".
 
 Likewise, I don't see why we should overlook PRECISELY WHAT the anti-gay side is asking for when we are talking about who is "hateful" in a debate.
 To me, the pro-gay side would have to create some "hateful" advances just to offset the "hateful" nature of the discussion in the first place.
 
 
 
And yes, something like "you people" is an example (though mild; I've certainly seen a lot worse such as instantly resorting to namecalling that some do). 

 Let's cut through the XXXX.
 When "you people" is offensive, it's because it involves a stereo-type.
 Like referring to blacks as "you people" and pretending they all think alike or some similar generalizing comment.
 The "you people" isn't inherently offensive. It's what it can represent.
 
 In this, "you people" was referring to anti-gay people.
 If you substitute "anti-gay people" in for "you people", there is no real offense that I can see.
 "You people" is not inherently offensive. It's the CONTEXT of the statement which makes it offensive. Not the phrase itself.
 
 
 
Another might be the way you've thrown this thread completely off-track from the whole issue of the BYU professor.

 What dishonest obfuscation you demonstrate.
 I responded to your post about the issue, and made a comment ABOUT YOUR side-comment.
 
 And that is all anybody has focused on ever since.
 
 So YOU started this whole "off-track" XXXX with your wild accusation.
snakespit

Like I said, I understand it's a private university and they have their rules. I just don't see the point of having a university if they aren't going to have some leeway on their views of their professors.  It's not like this guy was out carrying picket signs or anything, and there's no evidence he was teaching his views in class. He just made a statement of opinion that the public heard about.  Impeding peoples' freedom to believe things scares me. I'm just saying I think this goes a bit too far in terms of the policy and policing by BYU.

 Clearly spelled out in their code of ethics that they expect a certain level of behavior and moral "correctness" (as diluded as it is). They make no secret of the fact that this is their stance, and these are the consequences of going against that stance. Do I think it is a "good" moral position...no. Do I think that they provided ample opportunity for this situation to be avoided in the first place...you bet. I say good for BYU. Finally a religious organization that actually practices what it preaches. How nauseatingly refreshing. 
 
 
yes, they do. But that doesn't make it right. This action may have had harmful effect on the professor and his family. I don't think anyone here is questioning the legality of what BYU did.

 I did not say that it was right as in a moral sense of "right or wrong". Obviously I think that hatred, bigotry, and intolerance are poor values to be taught by any organization...especially one with a religious affiliation. All I was really trying to say was that the professor had ample opportunity to understand the consequences of making such a view public. I am not judging the legality of the situation at all. My point was that the professor knew what could happen, and knowingly brought it upon himself. 
 
 It's like if I were gay, and decided to join the Army. I know going in that they have a "don't ask, don't tell" policy. I think it is a rediculous policy, but I am aware of it all the same. 1 year after joining, I walk into the CO's office, and tell him I'm gay. Now if I get kicked out, should I really be surprised or upset? After all, I was completely aware of the policy going in, yet chose to to ignore it. 
 
 I simply solve situations such as this by doing 1 simple thing. If I don't agree with the policies, ethics, or code of an organization, I do not become involved in it.

http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2006/06/15/byu
 
 
"I didn't think they would let me go. They have every right to do that, but I think it was the wrong decision. It will breed a culture of fear and uncertainty. Academic institutions shouldn't restrict honest opinion and the pursuit of truth."

 
 
That a faculty member is being let go for a respectful comment is a disgrace to the university," said Firmage, a BYU alumnus. "People can differ on what the gospel teaches - part of it is liberty and freedom. The word 'university' should mean something. This isn't Brigham Young Seminary."
